title: Safe Sex When You’re HIV-Positive
author: Markham Heid

content: If you are HIV-positive, you can still have sex. In some cases, you can even have unprotected sex without putting your partner or partners at risk for HIV.

The steps you need to take to protect yourself and your partner depend on several things. These include whether you’re treating your HIV with medication. It also matters if you or your partner have recently had unprotected sex with someone who may have HIV.
Learn how you can have safe sex. That means protecting yourself and your partners.

content_blocks.text: If you are HIV-positive, you can still have sex. In some cases, you can even have unprotected sex without putting your partner or partners at risk for HIV.

The steps you need to take to protect yourself and your partner depend on several things. These include whether you’re treating your HIV with medication. It also matters if you or your partner have recently had unprotected sex with someone who may have HIV.
Learn how you can have safe sex. That means protecting yourself and your partners.

sections.heading: Get ART
content: Antiretroviral therapy , or ART, is medication that stops HIV from damaging your immune system. The medications lower the amount of HIV in your body if taken daily as prescribed. It can take several weeks for ART to start working.

If taken daily as prescribed, ART works so well that the tests can’t find HIV in your blood. Doctors call this an undetectable viral load. That means you can’t infect anyone with HIV through sex. It may take six months for ART to lower your viral load enough to make unprotected sex safe.

content_blocks.text: Antiretroviral therapy , or ART, is medication that stops HIV from damaging your immune system. The medications lower the amount of HIV in your body if taken daily as prescribed. It can take several weeks for ART to start working.

If taken daily as prescribed, ART works so well that the tests can’t find HIV in your blood. Doctors call this an undetectable viral load. That means you can’t infect anyone with HIV through sex. It may take six months for ART to lower your viral load enough to make unprotected sex safe.

content: Even if you’re HIV-positive, you can still get infected with a different strain of the virus. So protect yourself if you’re not sure of your partner’s status. You can use a condom if you're unsure, and it protects you from other types of STDs, too.
If you’re on ART, you will need a blood test every three to four months to monitor your viral load. Some people may never reach undetectable viral levels.

content_blocks.text: Even if you’re HIV-positive, you can still get infected with a different strain of the virus. So protect yourself if you’re not sure of your partner’s status. You can use a condom if you're unsure, and it protects you from other types of STDs, too.
If you’re on ART, you will need a blood test every three to four months to monitor your viral load. Some people may never reach undetectable viral levels.

sections.heading: Use Condoms
content: Condoms worn by both women and men greatly lower the chances that you’ll pass on or catch HIV.

The amount of protection depends on how you and your partner are having sex. Anal sex has the highest risk of passing on HIV. For example, you have a 1 in 72 chance of an HIV infection each time you are the person receiving anal sex, if your insertive partner has HIV and you both don't take HIV medications.
Wearing a male condom cuts that risk by 72%, or about 7 in 1,800.

Wearing a male condom cuts that risk by 72%, or about 7 in 1,800.

sections.heading: Use Condoms
content: Condoms worn by both women and men greatly lower the chances that you’ll pass on or catch HIV.

The amount of protection depends on how you and your partner are having sex. Anal sex has the highest risk of passing on HIV. For example, you have a 1 in 72 chance of an HIV infection each time you are the person receiving anal sex, if your insertive partner has HIV and you both don't take HIV medications.
Wearing a male condom cuts that risk by 72%, or about 7 in 1,800.

content_blocks.text: Condoms worn by both women and men greatly lower the chances that you’ll pass on or catch HIV.

The amount of protection depends on how you and your partner are having sex. Anal sex has the highest risk of passing on HIV. For example, you have a 1 in 72 chance of an HIV infection each time you are the person receiving anal sex, if your insertive partner has HIV and you both don't take HIV medications.
Wearing a male condom cuts that risk by 72%, or about 7 in 1,800.

content: Next riskiest is if you’re the person on top during anal sex. You have a 1 in 909 chance of getting HIV from your partner without a condom.

If you’re female, you have a slightly lower chance, or 1 in 1,250, of getting an infection during unprotected vaginal sex with an HIV-positive partner. Using a condom lowers that risk by an average of 80%.
Oral sex poses little or no risk of HIV transmission. Placing a condom on the penis or inside the vagina lowers that risk even more.
Remember that without condoms, you and your partner can still catch other sexually transmitted diseases such as gonorrhea and chlamydia .

If you’re female, you have a slightly lower chance, or 1 in 1,250, of getting an infection during unprotected vaginal sex with an HIV-positive partner. Using a condom lowers that risk by an average of 80%.
Oral sex poses little or no risk of HIV transmission. Placing a condom on the penis or inside the vagina lowers that risk even more.
Remember that without condoms, you and your partner can still catch other sexually transmitted diseases such as gonorrhea and chlamydia .

sections.heading: Get PrEP and PEP
content: Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is a preventive medicine that stops HIV from taking hold or spreading in your body. You take this treatment when you don’t have HIV but may be at a high risk of getting infected by your partner.
If you take PrEP as instructed, your risk for getting HIV will fall by 99%. But it takes at least:
bullets: Seven days for PrEP to protect you if you're having receptive anal sex.
Twenty-one days for PrEP to protect you if you're having receptive vaginal sex or injecting drugs.

content_blocks.text: Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is a preventive medicine that stops HIV from taking hold or spreading in your body. You take this treatment when you don’t have HIV but may be at a high risk of getting infected by your partner.
If you take PrEP as instructed, your risk for getting HIV will fall by 99%. But it takes at least:
associated_bullets: Seven days for PrEP to protect you if you're having receptive anal sex.
Twenty-one days for PrEP to protect you if you're having receptive vaginal sex or injecting drugs.

content: You can take PrEP as a daily pill or as a shot. It depends on the brand, but you can get a bimonthly or biyearly shot.

Post-exposure prophylaxis , or PEP, is an emergency form of treatment. You take it if you’ve recently had sex that might have exposed you to HIV. You must take PEP as soon as possible, and no later than within 72 hours of having sex. Otherwise, the medicine won’t help.

Oral sex poses little or no risk of HIV transmission. Placing a condom on the penis or inside the vagina lowers that risk even more.
Remember that without condoms, you and your partner can still catch other sexually transmitted diseases such as gonorrhea and chlamydia .

meta_description: You can have sex safely if you or your partner has HIV. Find out what helps lower your risk.
